case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the assessee

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 312 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 312 of 1959. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 23, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 21 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 23, 1956 of Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 21 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 23, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 21 of 1956. Hardyal Hardy and D. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KAPUR, J. on December 6, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 6. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave brought by the Commissioner of Income-tax against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay

facts.text: Appeal by special leave by Commissioner of Income-tax against Bombay High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave brought by the Commissioner of Income-tax against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay answering the question in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Question referred by Tribunal: Whether Rs. 3,20,162 is allowable deduction under Section 10(2)(xi) or 10(2)(xv) of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question referred by the Tribunal was Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the amount of Rs. 3,20,162 is an allowable deduction under Section 10 2  xi  or 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act?

facts.text: High Court amended question and answered in affirmative in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: which was amended by the High Court as follows Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the amount Rs. 3,20,162 is an allowable deduction and was answered in the affirmative and against the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent is registered firm carrying on business as commission agents.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case shortly stated are these The respondent is a registered firm carrying on business as companymission agents.

facts.text: Respondent treated as agent of non-resident principal Haji Mohamed Syed Ali Barbari of Port Sudan.

anchor.surface_text: It was treated as the agent of a number- resident principal Haji Mohamed Syed Ali Barbari of Port Sudan  hereinafter referred to as the numberresident principal.

facts.text: Respondent's business: export of cloth and kariana to Aden, Saudi Arabia and Sudan.

anchor.surface_text: It was carrying on the business of export of cloth and kariana  i.e., miscellaneous goods  to Aden, Saudi Arabia and sudan.

facts.text: Respondent supplied goods from India to non-resident principal; principal sent cotton to respondent for sale in India.

anchor.surface_text: It used to supply goods from India to the numberresident principal, who on his part, was sending companyton to the respondent and other merchants for sale in India.

facts.text: For years 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46, respondent treated as agent under s.43 of Income-tax Act for income-tax and Excess Profits Tax.

anchor.surface_text: For the years 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45 and 1945-46, the respondent firm was treated as the agent of the numberresident principal under s. 43 of the Income-tax Act

facts.text: Respondent paid Rs. 3,78,491 under s.42(1) of Income-tax Act; principal's account showed debit balance of Rs. 3,20,162 after adjustments.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent firm had to pay in all Rs. 3,78,491 under s. 42 1  of the Act and after allowing for the amounts which were in its hands the account of the principal number-resident showed a debit balance of Rs. 3,20,162.

facts.text: For assessment year 1953-54, respondent claimed Rs. 3,20,162 as bad debt deductible loss.

anchor.surface_text: For the year of assessment, 1953-54, the respondent firm treated this amount as a bad debt and claimed it as a deductible loss to be set off against profits.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed claim under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer treating this claim as one under s. 10 2  xv  of the Act, disallowed it.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed under s.10(2)(xi).

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner treated it as one under s. 10  2  xi  of the Act and he also disallowed it.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held it allowable bad debt as result of business with non-resident principal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal it was held to be a bad debt and an allowable deduction as it was incurred as a result of the business activities which the respondent firm was carrying on with the numberresident principal.

facts.text: High Court modified question and answered affirmative against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, the case was stated to the High Court and the High Court modified the question and answered the same in the affirmative, i.e., against the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court judgment, answers question against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was in error in answering the question in favour of the respondent. We therefore allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court and answer the question against the respondent.

facts.text: Liability imposed under s.42(2) due to close connection in business with non-resident.

anchor.surface_text: The liability to pay arises under a. 42 2  which provides Where a person number resident or number ordinarily resident in the taxable territories carries on business with a person resident in the taxable territories, and it appears to the Income-tax Officer that owing to the close companynection between such persons

facts.text: High Court held amount deductible under s.10(1) as business loss.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that as the law imposed an obligation upon the respondent firm to discharge the liability and-it was incidental to the business of the respondent the amount was a deductible loss and even if it was number a debt, then also the amount companyld be claimed by the assessee as a business or trading loss

anchor.surface_text: Hence even if a deduction is not specifically enumerated in sub-section (2) of s. 10 it would still be a debatable item to reflect the taxable profits. The Privy Council in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Sir S. M. Chitnavis held that the Act nowhere authorises the deduction of bad debts of a business, such a deduction is necessarily allowable because what is chargeable to income-tax in respect of a business are the profits and gains of a year and in assessing the amount of profits and gains of that, year account must necessarily be taken of all losses incurred, otherwise true profits and gains cannot be ascertained.

concepts.interpretation: Account must be taken of all losses to ascertain true profits and gains of the business

anchor.surface_text: In order that a loss may be deductible it must be a loss in the business of the assessee and not payment relating to the business of somebody else which under the provisions of the Act is deemed to be and becomes the liability of the assessee. The loss becomes allowable if it springs directly from and is incidental to the business of the assessee.

arguments.claim: Loss deductible under s.10(1) as per true profits principle, accounting for all losses (citing Chitnavis); incidental if springs from business

anchor.surface_text: The thing to be taxed, said Lord Halsbury, L. C., is the amount of profits and gains. The word profits I think is to be understood in its natural and proper sense-in a sense which no commercial man would misunderstand Gresham Life Assurance Society V. Styles . Hence even if a deduction is not specifically enumerated in sub-section (2) of s. 10 it would still be a debatable item to reflect the taxable profits. The Privy Council in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Sir S. M. Chitnavis held that the Act nowhere authorises the deduction of bad debts of a business, such a deduction is necessarily allowable because what is chargeable to income-tax in respect of a business are the profits and gains of a year and in assessing the amount of profits and gains of that, year account must necessarily be taken of all losses incurred, otherwise true profits and gains cannot be ascertained. In order that a loss may be deductible it must be a loss in the business of the assessee

arguments.claim: Loss by agent's embezzlement deductible under s.10(1) as incidental to business (Badridas Daga)

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent relied upon a judgment of this Court in Badridas Daga v. The Commissioner of Income-tax . In that case an agent of the assessee engaged for the purpose of carrying on of the assessees business had authority to operate a bank account. Acting under such authority the agent withdrew from the bank monies and put them to his personal use. The assessee was able to recover from the agent only a part of the amount misappropriated and the balance was written off as irrecoverable debt and it was held that it was not allowable under s. 10 2  xi  or 10 2  xv  of the Act but it was a loss deductible in computing the profits under s. 10 1  of the Act as a loss incidental to the carrying on of his business.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l depend on whether having regard to accepted companymercial practice and trading principles it can be said to arise out of the carrying on of the bus

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: in that case incidental to assessee's business via agent employment; here deemed for another's business

arguments.claim: Bad debt must be trading debt that would enter balance sheet to swell profits (Curtis case)

anchor.surface_text: Reference may also be made to an English decision in Curtis J. G. Oldfield Ltd. . In that case the managing director of a company of wine and spirit merchants embezzled monies of the company and that. was claimed as a loss as a bad debt and it was held that it was not a trading loss and was therefore not an admissible deduction. ... Rowlatt, J., said at p. 330 When the Rule speaks of a bad debt it means a debt which is a debt that would have come into the balance-sheet as a trading debt in the trade that is in question and that it is bad.

arguments.claim: Embezzlement loss by employee deductible as trading loss (Lord's Dairy Farm)

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent also relied on Lords Dairy Farm Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay . That was a case of embezzlement by an employee and it was held that the loss directly arose from the necessity of employing cashiers and therefore the loss by embezzlement was a trading loss

It was held in that case that the expression profits and gains has to be understood in its commercial sense and that there could be no computation of profits and gains until the expenditure necessary for earning those profits and gains is deducted therefrom

holdings.text: In our opinion the High Court was in error in answering the question in favour of the respondent. We therefore allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court and answer the question against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was in error in answering the question in favour of the respondent. We therefore allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court and answer the question against the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The claimed amount is neither a bad debt under s.10(2)(xi)/(xv) nor a deductible business loss under s.10(1) as it arises from deemed liability under s.42(2) for non-resident's business, not incidental to assessee's own business.

holdings.text: In our opinion the amount which became payable by the respondent firm cannot be called its business loss.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the amount which became payable by the respondent firm cannot be called its business loss. In order to be deductible the loss must be in the nature of a commercial loss and, as has been said above, must spring directly out of it and must really be incidental to the business itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loss must spring directly from and be incidental to the assessee's business; here it is a deemed liability relating to non-resident principal's business under s.42(2).

holdings.text: the loss which the respondent has incurred is not in its own business but the liability arose because of the business of another person and that is not a permissible deduction within s. 10 1 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As we have said above, that condition has not been fulfilled and the loss which the respondent has incurred is not in its own business but the liability arose because of the business of another person and that is not a permissible deduction within s. 10 1 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability imposed under s.42(1) and (2) due to agency for non-resident does not constitute a business debt, trading debt, or loss incidental to respondent's business.

holdings.text: This contention has even less substance than the claim of deduction under s. 10 1 . Under cl. xi also a debt is only allowable when it is a debt and arises out of and as an incident to the trade.

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended that the matter falls within s. 10 2 xi of the Act, i.e., it is in respect of the busi- ness. This contention has even less substance than the claim of deduction under s. 10 1 . Under cl. xi also a debt is only allowable when it is a debt and arises out of and as an incident to the trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The amount is not a debt arising out of and incidental to the assessee's trade, required for deduction under s.10(2)(xi).

holdings.text: In order that a loss may be deductible it must be a loss in the business of the assessee and not payment relating to the business of somebody else which under the provisions of the Act is deemed to be and becomes the liability of the assessee. The loss becomes allowable if it springs directly from and is incidental to the business of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In order that a loss may be deductible it must be a loss in the business of the assessee and not payment relating to the business of somebody else which under the provisions of the Act is deemed to be and becomes the liability of the assessee. The loss becomes allowable if it springs directly from and is incidental to the business of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deductibility under s.10(1) requires loss to be in assessee's business, not deemed liability for another's business; follows true profits principle from precedents like Chitnavis.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the amount which became payable by the respondent firm cannot be called its business loss. In order to be deductible the loss must be in the nature of a commercial loss and, as has been said above, must spring directly out of it and must really be incidental to the business itself.
We therefore allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court and answer the question against the respondent.

This contention has even less substance than the claim of deduction under s. 10 1 . Under cl. xi also a debt is only allowable when it is a debt and arises out of and as an incident to the trade.
We therefore allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court and answer the question against the respondent.
